newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast prods steady amid refinery repairs.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast prods steady amid refinery repairs.

text.p: Refinery repairs kept U.S. West Coast products steady despite a fall in NYMEX prices early Wednesday, traders said.
Milder forecasts for the northeast U.S., a key heating oil region, initially weighed down energy futures before a slight rebound in late New York trade.
January heating oil fell as much 1.39 cents a gallon to 72.15 cents, while gasoline shed 1.17 cents amid the weather news and talk of profit-taking.
Early West Coast spot trade was active but stable despite the volatile futures, traders said.
A recent spate of refinery problems in California left perceptions of tighter supplies among traders.
- A fluid catalytic cracker at Chevron's Richmond plant, slated to return December 25 following an early December tube problem.
- A hydrocracker shut Dec. 7 for an unspecified period at Unocal's Wilmington refinery.
- Lost output from two cokers damaged in a late November fire at Mobil's Torrance refinery.
West Coast dealers bought and sold December gasoline for the fourth cycle, traders said.
December CARB gasoline was talked between 71 and 72 cents a gallon in Los Angeles, easing a half cent from late Tuesday as local tightness offset sharp NYMEX declines.
CARB-grade gasoline for January was also talked about 0.50 cent lower at 73/74 cents a gallon, with a parcel sold in L.A. for 74 cents.
December barrels of conventional gasoline eased 0.50 cent to 70/71 cents in the L.A. market.
January CARB diesel was nearly flat from Tuesday at 73/74 cents a gallon, with December trade ended. Low sulphur diesel sold for 70.50 cents, even with yesterday, traders said.
In Portland, Oregon conventional unleaded gasoline was bought at 64.50 cents, brokers said.
